Recall Fermat's Little Theorem to see if it can simplify the computation of \(3^{105} \mod 11\) and \(4^{105} \mod 11\).
Apply Fermat's Little Theorem to find \(3^{10} \mod 11\) and \(4^{10} \mod 11\).
Calculate \(3^{105}\) as \((3^{10})^{10} \times 3^5\) and find its value modulo 11.
Calculate \(4^{105}\) as \((4^{10})^{10} \times 4^5\) and find its value modulo 11.
Sum the results of \(3^{105} \mod 11\) and \(4^{105} \mod 11\).
Find the modulo 11 of the final sum to get \(3^{105} + 4^{105} \mod 11\).

Recognize patterns and properties of powers with modulus, specifically for the numbers 3^105 and 4^105 modulo 11.
Use Fermat's Little Theorem, which states that if p is a prime number, then for any integer a, the number a^p - a is an integer multiple of p. Apply this to simplify 3^105 mod 11 and 4^105 mod 11.
Calculate the modulus of smaller powers for both bases 3 and 4 with respect to 11 up to the power of 10, as patterns often repeat within the range of a prime number.
Identify repeated cycles or patterns in the sequence of powers for each base (3 and 4) which can be utilized to predict the values of larger powers like 3^105 and 4^105.
Use the results from the earlier steps to determine 3^105 mod 11 and 4^105 mod 11 without direct calculation of the large powers.
Add the two results from 3^105 mod 11 and 4^105 mod 11 according to modular arithmetic rules.
Compute the modulus of the sum to find (3^105 + 4^105) mod 11.
